title: Neuro-Behcet's Disease
icd10: G09 (Sequelae of inflammatory diseases of central nervous system)
I67.6 (Nonpyogenic thrombosis of intracranial venous system)
scope: ** Diagnostic workup and management of suspected or confirmed Neuro-Behcet's disease across both parenchymal (brainstem predominant, hemispheric, spinal cord, optic nerve) and non-parenchymal (cerebral venous thrombosis, intracranial hypertension, meningitis) forms. Covers International Study Group (ISG) diagnostic criteria, International Criteria for Behcet's Disease (ICBD), HLA-B51 testing, pathergy test, acute immunotherapy, steroid-sparing agents, and biologic therapies (TNF inhibitors). Settings: ED, HOSP, OPD, ICU. For isolated mucocutaneous or ocular Behcet's disease without neurological involvement, defer to rheumatology/dermatology/ophthalmology. For other CNS vasculitides (e.g., PACNS, giant cell arteritis, neurosarcoidosis), use respective templates.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology specialist) for diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy guidance, and long-term management
Rheumatology for systemic Behcet's disease co-management, mucocutaneous disease control, and immunosuppression coordination
Ophthalmology for urgent slit lamp examination (uveitis screening), fluorescein angiography, OCT; **Ocular Behcet's occurs in 50-70% and causes blindness if untreated**
Hematology if CVT (non-parenchymal NBD): anticoagulation management, thrombophilia evaluation
Dermatology for skin lesion biopsy (erythema nodosum, pseudofolliculitis, pathergy test interpretation) and mucocutaneous disease management
Neurosurgery for ICP management (EVD/VP shunt) if refractory intracranial hypertension from CVT; brain biopsy if diagnosis uncertain
Vascular surgery/interventional radiology if pulmonary artery aneurysm (Hughes-Stovin syndrome) or large vessel vasculitis
Oral medicine/dentistry for recurrent oral aphthous ulcer management; topical therapies
Gastroenterology if GI Behcet's suspected (abdominal pain, GI bleeding, ulceration)
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given brainstem/spinal cord involvement
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and functional rehabilitation
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation if brainstem involvement (bulbar symptoms) and cognitive-linguistic rehabilitation
Neuropsychology for cognitive assessment and rehabilitation given parenchymal NBD cognitive impairment
Social work for insurance navigation, disability resources, and psychosocial support
Infusion center coordination for IV methylprednisolone, infliximab, tocilizumab, rituximab, or cyclophosphamide infusions
Fertility specialist for reproductive counseling before initiating teratogenic immunosuppressants (methotrexate, mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide)
Pain management for refractory headache or neuropathic pain not responding to first-line agents
Urology for neurogenic bladder evaluation and management if myelopathic NBD

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for sudden vision loss, new weakness, difficulty walking, severe headache, seizures, difficulty breathing, or new oral/genital ulcers with neurological symptoms (indicates disease flare or complications)
Neuro-Behcet's disease is a chronic, treatable condition -- improvement is gradual over weeks to months with appropriate immunotherapy; relapses are common and require prompt treatment
Do NOT stop corticosteroids abruptly as this causes adrenal crisis and disease flare; taper under physician supervision only
Report signs of infection immediately (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash, wound redness) as immunosuppressive therapy increases infection risk
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy (inform all physicians and pharmacists of immunosuppression status)
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic or on corticosteroids -- steroids significantly elevate blood glucose
Do not drive until cleared by neurology if visual impairment, seizures, or significant neurological deficits are present
Keep a symptom diary tracking oral ulcers, genital ulcers, visual changes, headaches, weakness, numbness, and skin lesions to monitor disease activity and treatment response
Take azathioprine with food to reduce GI side effects; report severe nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain (indicates pancreatitis)
Take methotrexate on the same day each week; take folic acid daily EXCEPT on methotrexate day to reduce side effects
If on warfarin for CVT: attend all INR checks; report bleeding or bruising; avoid excess foods high in vitamin K; report any new medications
Avoid pregnancy during methotrexate, mycophenolate, or cyclophosphamide therapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN
Attend all follow-up appointments -- Neuro-Behcet's requires regular monitoring with MRI, labs, clinical assessments, and ophthalmologic exams
Wear medical alert identification (bracelet/card) indicating Behcet's disease, immunosuppressive medications, and anticoagulation status if applicable
Use sun protection while on immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to reduce vascular risk and improve treatment outcomes
Alcohol avoidance or strict limitation while on methotrexate, azathioprine, or other hepatotoxic immunosuppressants
Low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention and hypertension from corticosteroid therapy
Calcium-rich diet for bone protection during chronic steroid use
Regular weight-bearing exercise as tolerated to prevent steroid-related osteoporosis and deconditioning
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day) especially if on methotrexate or if thrombotic risk present
Fall prevention measures at home given brainstem/cerebellar involvement and balance impairment
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) as stress exacerbates Behcet's disease activity
Update all vaccinations before initiating immunosuppressive therapy (pneumococcal, influenza, hepatitis B, COVID-19); avoid live vaccines on immunosuppression
Sun protection (SPF 50+, protective clothing) during immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk
Dental hygiene with soft toothbrush and non-irritating toothpaste to minimize oral ulcer triggers
Annual ophthalmologic examination even if asymptomatic due to risk of subclinical uveitis, retinal vasculitis, and steroid-related cataracts/glaucoma
Report any new venous thrombosis symptoms (leg swelling, chest pain, shortness of breath) immediately given systemic thrombotic tendency in Behcet's

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; periventricular/juxtacortical/infratentorial/spinal cord lesions (Dawson fingers); oligoclonal bands more common; NO oral/genital ulcers; NO pathergy; predominantly female
differential.tests: MRI pattern (MS: periventricular, Dawson fingers vs. NBD: brainstem-diencephalic); CSF OCBs (common in MS, uncommon in NBD); HLA-B51 negative; no mucocutaneous features

differential.features: Non-caseating granulomas; cranial neuropathies (especially CN VII); leptomeningeal enhancement; hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated serum ACE; no oral/genital ulcers
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); serum ACE; biopsy (granulomas vs. vasculitis); CSF ACE; HLA-B51 negative; no pathergy

differential.features: Progressive headache; multifocal strokes; angiographic beading; no systemic mucocutaneous features; any age
differential.tests: Cerebral angiography (beading); brain/meningeal biopsy (transmural vasculitis); no oral/genital ulcers; no pathergy; HLA-B51 negative

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; meningitis; Argyll Robertson pupils; cognitive decline; positive serology; sexual history
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS; no oral ulcers (chancre is different from aphthae); no pathergy

differential.features: Female predominance; malar rash; arthritis; serositis; ANA/anti-dsDNA positive; cerebritis; strokes from antiphospholipid
differential.tests: ANA; anti-dsDNA; complement levels; anti-phospholipid antibodies; no pathergy; different rash pattern

differential.features: No recurrent oral/genital ulcers; no systemic vasculitis features; often associated with prothrombotic states, OCP, pregnancy
differential.tests: Standard thrombophilia workup; no HLA-B51; no mucocutaneous features; no pathergy

differential.features: Subacute meningitis; basilar enhancement; CSF low glucose, high protein, elevated ADA; caseating granulomas; endemic areas
differential.tests: AFB culture/smear; CSF TB PCR; QuantiFERON-TB; biopsy (caseating granulomas); no oral/genital ulcers

differential.features: Progressive encephalopathy; periventricular enhancement; homogeneous enhancing mass; immunocompromised
differential.tests: CSF cytology/flow cytometry; brain biopsy; FDG-PET (intense uptake); no mucocutaneous features

differential.features: Dry eyes/mouth; anti-SSA/SSB positive; peripheral neuropathy more common than CNS; myelitis possible
differential.tests: Anti-SSA/SSB; Schirmer test; salivary gland biopsy; no oral ulcers (dry mouth instead); no pathergy

differential.features: Mass-forming lesions; pachymeningeal involvement; elevated serum IgG4; multi-organ fibrosis; orbital involvement
differential.tests: Serum IgG4; tissue biopsy (storiform fibrosis, IgG4+ plasma cells); no oral/genital ulcers; no pathergy

differential.features: Young women; psychiatric symptoms; seizures; movement disorder; ovarian teratoma
differential.tests: Anti-NMDA receptor antibody; ovarian imaging; no oral/genital ulcers; rapid onset

differential.features: Sinusitis; pulmonary nodules/cavities; glomerulonephritis; pachymeningeal enhancement; c-ANCA positive
differential.tests: c-ANCA (PR3); biopsy (necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis); no aphthous ulcers; no pathergy

differential.features: Cranial neuropathy (CN VII bilateral); meningitis; radiculopathy; erythema migrans; endemic area
differential.tests: Lyme serology; CSF Lyme antibody index; travel history; no oral/genital ulcers

differential.features: Monophasic; post-infectious; large multifocal demyelinating lesions; more common in children
differential.tests: Clinical context (post-viral/vaccine); no recurrent ulcers; no HLA-B51; typically monophasic vs. relapsing NBD

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (brainstem signs, motor, sensory, gait, cognition, cranial nerves)
monitoring.action: If worsening: urgent re-imaging; escalate immunotherapy; neurosurgery consult if ICP concerns
Worsening: urgent ophthalmology; escalate steroids; add anti-TNF
Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250 mg/dL
Antihypertensive therapy; steroid dose adjustment if severe
Rule out infection; blood cultures if febrile on immunosuppression

monitoring.frequency: Q6h until therapeutic x 2, then q12-24h
monitoring.action: Adjust heparin infusion per protocol; watch for HIT

monitoring.frequency: Daily until target INR x 2 days
monitoring.action: Adjust warfarin dose; overlap heparin until INR therapeutic
CSF drainage; escalate ICP management; repeat imaging
Active new ulcers suggest systemic disease activity; escalate immunotherapy

disposition.criteria: Stable or improving neurological exam; seizure-free (if applicable); oral medications tolerated; anticoagulation therapeutic and stable (if CVT); steroid taper plan established; follow-up with neurology and rheumatology within 1-2 weeks; outpatient labs and imaging scheduled; family/caregiver education completed

New-onset or worsening parenchymal NBD requiring IV methylprednisolone; new CVT requiring heparin anticoagulation; diagnostic workup requiring expedited imaging and LP; new seizures requiring medication optimization; progressive brainstem syndrome; new visual loss from ocular/optic nerve involvement

Severe brainstem syndrome with bulbar dysfunction or decreased consciousness; acute elevated ICP from CVT not responding to medical management; status epilepticus; severe myelopathy with respiratory compromise; rapid neurological decline; large hemorrhagic venous infarct; impending herniation

Neurosurgery not available (ICP management, EVD, biopsy); neuroimmunology specialist not available; interventional radiology for endovascular CVT treatment; infusion center for biologic therapy not available
Significant functional deficits from brainstem syndrome, myelopathy, or hemispheric involvement; medically stable; expected to benefit from intensive PT/OT/ST; unable to safely return home

All discharged patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; rheumatology within 2-4 weeks; ophthalmology within 1-2 weeks; hematology if on anticoagulation; labs per monitoring schedule; MRI per protocol

New or worsening neurological symptoms (vision loss, weakness, brainstem signs, seizures, severe headache); infection on immunosuppression; suspected disease relapse; uncontrolled oral/genital ulcers suggesting flare; new thrombotic event; severe steroid side effects
